item.title: New Epic Encounters Steelborn Set Brings Steel Warriors To Your Game Night
item.content:encoded:
Steamforged Games has a new set of Epic Encounters boxes for pre-order. The new Epic Encounters Steelborn sets provide a prebuilt, ready-to-play Dungeons & Dragons encounter themed around steel constructs and clockwork automata for sci-fi inclined DMs.

The Epic Encounters Steelborn Set Pre-Order Announcement

According to its official store page, the Epic Encounters Steelborn set comprises two boxes. The first, Epic Encounters: Sanctuary of the Steelborn, is the minion encounter box. It contains 20 miniatures, an encounter booklet, and a double-sided encounter map designed for thematic, dynamic battles.

The second box, Epic Encounters: Realm of the Titan, is the boss box. It contains a single large boss miniature with a 120 mm base. An encounter booklet providing boss behaviors and abilities, several difficulty tiers, a set of tokens to represent minions, and a double-sided battle map as well.

The introduction of the Steelborn to Epic Encounters may be contentious on the surface. The central idea of Steamforged's product line is to provide challenging, exciting, fantasy battles based around iconic monster archetypes. Their line has ranged from undead skeletons to bandits to crab monsters, to dragons, to drow and driders.

At first glance, the Epic Encounters Steelborn sets appear to be at odds with high fantasy. But, for more seasoned members of the community, their inclusion is natural. Metal golems have been staples in various fantasy settings like The Elder Scrolls. Critical Role's Exandria setting features sophisticated automata. An entire Dungeons & Dragons setting, Eberron, is built around magic artificers and warforged. 

Epic Encounters is but one product line in Steamforged Games' catalog. The tabletop developer is known for high-quality bespoke licensed board games based on Runescape, Resident Evil, and Sea of Thieves, and ongoing support of the miniature game, Warmachine. They even launched an Epic Encounter spin-off line, Local Legends, which focuses more on engaging taverns and venues for players to enjoy.

Both boxes in the Epic Encounters Steelborn set are available for pre-order now at an MSRP of $54.99 each. These pre-orders will be available until October 7.

Ever since he was small, Tyler Chancey has had a deep, abiding love for video games and a tendency to think and overanalyze everything he enjoyed. This… More about Tyler

item.title: Wuchang: Fallen Feathers Update Seemingly Censors Game and Angers Fans
item.content:encoded:
Fans of the Soulslike action RPG Wuchang: Fallen Feathers are flocking to Steam to leave negative reviews owing to what appears to be an attempt at censoring some of the game's content in its latest update.

As noted by none other than Soulslike aficionado and Bloodborne modder Lance McDonald on social media (via Windows Central), Update 1.5, which was released recently, changes the game so that it's impossible to "kill any historically significant bosses or NPCs".

Instead, according to McDonald, these enemies and bosses simply "get 'exhausted' and relax after the fight and talk to you". It also seems as though a Pray emote, taught to the player by a Portuguese Christian missionary during the course of the game, has been removed.

According to McDonald, Wuchang: Fallen Feathers' fourth chapter is now "insanely easy" because half of the chapter's enemies will no longer attack you, and you also can't attack them, so a vast portion of that chapter's challenge has been removed.

Not only that, but the game's protagonist now also apparently pledges to "continue [the] legacy" of bosses she defeats, which, as McDonald notes, "literally ruin[s] the entire point of the game's plot about impermanence".

There are many more examples of these kinds of changes throughout McDonald's social media thread, and I'd recommend reading it if you want to know what's different after the update.

The official patch notes themselves don't really make reference to these changes, either; there's a brief note about adding "dialogs for some NPCs to complete some plots" and "further optimiz[ing] the exhaustion animations in the future to improve the plot performance", but nothing concrete.

Needless to say, these changes haven't exactly thrilled Steam users, with many leaving negative reviews decrying Wuchang: Fallen Feathers' "sudden" plot changes, "censorship", and attempts to appease "whiny Chinese nationalists".

Ironically, those complaints now appear to have overtaken the very "nationalist" ire the update was seemingly intended to address. Whether or not Leenzee will make further changes remains to be seen, but it does seem as though Wuchang: Fallen Feathers has been significantly changed through Update 1.5.

At any rate, if you'd like to check out the game, you can do so right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S, and it's also available as a Game Pass title. You can read our review of the game (pre-update 1.5, of course) right here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
